The City of Port St. Lucie's accidental release prevention and emergency response policies, integrate technology, procedures and management practices to assure safety of it's employees, the community and the environment.  In service to the community, the City has a history of dhering to proactive approaches for the prevention and emergency response of accidental releases of toxic substances.  Current prevention and emergency respone policies adhere to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Prevention Program and Emergency Response requirements as set forth under the 40 CFR 68 regulations.

The Facility is located in the City of Port St. Lucie, Florida and utilizes chlorine gas in the wastewater treatment process.  The Facility maintains a semi-enclosed (three walls and a roof, except that the side walls are constructed with vented block), chlorination area and chlorination distribution system on-site.  For modeling purposes, the chlorine facility is assumed to be not enclosed due to the aforementioned construction.  Chloine is delivered to the central area and stored on-site in cylinders containing 2,000 pounds of liquified chlorine under pressure when full.  The chlorine facility holds a maximum of four (4) 2,000 pound cylinders.

The Facility has an outstanding performance history in conjunction with the handling, storing, maintaining and operating of chlorine gas.  No accidental releases have occurred since the system went into service in 1985.  The wastewter treatment plant is manned 16 hours/day, seven (7) days/week, 365 days/year.  State certified operational personnel are trained in the safe handling, maintenance and operation of chlorine systems that comply with EPA 40 CFR 68 regulations.  The chlorination system is designed utilizing latest technologies and industry specific design codes and standards.  The current emergency response plans are documented and coordinated with the community emergency response oficials through the Local Emergency Planning

Committee (LEPC).  Operational staff are trained according to these response plans.

The EPA 40 CFR 68 requires offsite consequence analysis of two (2) release scenarios for toxic substances identified as "worst case release" and "alternative release."  The "worst case elease" is defined by EPA as "the owner/operator shall assume that the ? maximum quantity in the largest vessel? is released as a gas over 10 minutes."  For the worst case release, EPA specifies the parameters to use in calculating the distance the chlorine will travel to achieve its "toxic endpoint."  The alternative release is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst case release scenario", such as a pipe leak.

Utilizing the EPA's RMP* COMP Model, a distance of 4.3 miles was calculated for the worst case release toxic endpoint and 0.30 miles for the alternative release. For the alternative release.  It is noted that if an actual release did occur according to the alternative release scenario, the population at risk would be substantially less due to the plume of gas being more in the form of an elliptical pattern moving down wind of the point source rather than a circle centered on the point source.

The use of chlorination within wastewater treatment has yielded enofmous benefits in this County related to preventing the spread of water borne diseases.  The City, like other modern treatment facilities, understands the value and risks of this treatment procedure.  The City has an exceptional track record of no accidental releases in its history and remains ever vigilant in its attention to safety regrding chlorine.  The City supports this regulatory effort to inform the public in the general vicinity of any utility of the risks associated with accidental gaseous releases.  Indeed, we support ef

forts to notify the public of such risks at all points of exposure including the production, delivery and site storage of chlorine gas.

If you have questions on this matter, you may contact the offices of the City of Port St. Lucie Utility Systems Department, 900 SE Ogden Lane, Port St. Lucie, FL  34983 (772) 873-6400.
